text: This is what Im talking about. What a nice Lager style beer. The malts and Hops balance together smoothly to make a nice grain profile to the beer. Slight malt off taste at the end, but kinda also makes the beer enjoyable. Definitely a go to session beer.

Wont be drinking again. Penn Gold is better example of this style (as far as taste).  Still trying to find a brew from Great Lakes Brewing that I like.

Taste is pretty similar to the aroma. Has a medium-light body with a semi creamy mouthfeel and a semi dry, slightly bitter, medium finish. Overall, a tasty, easy drinking, sessionable helles.
Nice and crisp with great body and underlying structure. This is what I always hope for in a lager. Very good and clean. I feel this would be a great intro to craft beer for non-craft beer drinkers.

DATE: August 11, 2016... OCCASION: fighting through intense back strain--a first--while contemplating camp tomorrow... GLASSWARE: Hennepin pokal... sparse, swirling gold bubbles churn upward as clusters cling around the glasss side... an off-white head goes from two fingers to an uneven, rocky, mess of bubbles and smears... in contrast, the body is the picture of golden amber, crystal clear... caramel malts and bread dough mesh with light, flowery hops that tantalize.. the first sip is hearty, medium-bodied, and balanced, though the subtle touch on the teeth is bettered by the breaths malty finish... the finish itself is conditioned, with a palpable sweetness... at 30 IBUs, more hoppy than the average lager--a bouquet of flowers and slight citrus (melon and grapefruit)... rich in its malty sweetness, with caramel, slight nuttiness and the requisite bread dough.. meanwhile, the overlying experience is enjoyable, drinkable and flavorful in equal aspects... (yet another) success for the Great Lakes guys, that 5.8% ABV sticks a stronger edge to the session lager...

Im not typically a lager fan, but this is an amazing beer and one of my favorites.

12 oz bottle, poured into a shaker pint at approximately 45 degrees F.

A: Pours a crystal clear pale orange, leaning towards gold but definitely more on the orange side of that line, with a fair amount of bubbles visible. The head is fairly thing, and rather short-lived before dying to a ring of white and eventually, nothing at all.

S: Bread, is the main takeaway from the aroma. Whole grain bread, with extra whole grains and some cracked grains along for the ride. Theres some very faint toffee essence in there, and a little dry mustiness, like a long-sealed library being cracked open for the first time in decades.

T: The scent did not lie - whole grain bread flavor is present, and in spades. This has significant bread and grain malt character, for most of the tasting process. Theres a leathery soil note, however, that cuts through any possible sweetness, and is especially strong on the finish, leaving a bitter, clay-earth aftertaste. There are some other, very faint notes present, grassy and fruity, but the bitter soil conceals them enough that I am unable to pick them out.

M: Light and slick in the mouth, and rather sharply carbonated.

O: Not my favorite lager, to be honest, but this is also not my favorite lager style. The earthen noble hops are present enough to obscure some of the other flavors for me, and the malt tones are less biscuit, more bread and grain, to me. I usually avoid this one, and the occasional revisit reinforces to me why I do.

Bottle: Ive tried this beer multiple times from a bottle & on tap. I want to love it, I want to see the greatness that everyone else sees... But me & this beer have just never "meshed" well. Cloudy, golden-orange body with a small, white, quickly dissipating head. Aroma is sweet pils malt & some backing graininess with a sharp, musty, cheese-like note that overcasts everything. Sweaty, dirty cheese. Also some sweetbread & hints of sweet corn. Taste has a little sting of some earthy, Saaz-like hops, along with a touch of florals before Im send into the strange cheesiness of the brew again. Bottle from coldbrewky, many thanks. Golden color with small white head. Aroma of malt, hops and fruity syrup. Taste, strongly in floral hops, than some orange hints. Nice light bitter finish.

1. Look  A very clear pale gold color lager with a solid white head and lots of bubbles.
2. Sniff  It has a bready nose and a soft presence of alcohol.
3. Sip  This light bodied lager is tasty.  There is big malt flavor with a crisp finish.
4. Another Look  This is lager has good carbonation and a solid lacing.  
5. Evaluate  Overall, this is a very enjoyable lager that is easy to drink and would pair well with lighter foods.  I would absolutely recommend to the average mainstream lager drinkers for a change of pace.  This is absolutely a lager I will be picking up again soon.

12 oz bottle.  Pours bronze with a foamy, long lasting, white head and a lot of lacing.  Biscuit malt aroma is balanced by perfume hops and tropical fruit.  Medium, slightly crisp body.  Biscuit malt and spicy, herbal hops fill the mouth.  Some DMS come through.  Long, bitter finish.  Good brew, but too much DMS makes me take off some points.

bottle.  Poured clear amber with a thin white head. Aroma is grassy with lemon. Medium body, fizzy carbonated mouthfeel. Flavour is grainy and bitter with a little pepper, some malt shows up as the it warms up.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a pilsner glass.Appearance: Darker than your average lager with an amber/orange color; crystal clear; massive carbonation visible. Forms a large, white, frothy head which retains and laces very well.Smell: Typical clean-style, Bavarian Purity Law-conforming lager. No adjuncts; slight grassy hops; hints of lemon peel. Taste: Beers like Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold are the most difficult beers to review. Its lager in its purest form - fairly mild palate with few distinct flavors and the one that are there are subtle. Few craft beer enthusiasts are lager enthusiasts and Im certainly not one of them. The beer is so named for all the awards it has garnered, yet nothing stands out to me about the palate here that is noteworthy. At the same time there is absolutely nothing that turns me off, either.The palate is difficult to describe. Fairly generic lager flavor throughout. The difference between this and one of the big boys is theres not obvious presence of adjuncts. I get a slight hop spice and minor cracker-like maltiness but its not a beer I would describe as being bitter or sweet. It finishes clean and is very refreshing. Does that make it a great beer? Not by my standards since I dont grade to style, but if you like it - more power to you.Mouthfeel: Fairly thin (although Ive had thinner); fizzy, wet, clean with no aftertaste.Drinkability: If theres one thing this beer has going for it, its the drinkability. The mild palate is thirst-quenching and the clean finish makes it a beer you dont have to think about. I certainly never wouldve guessed this is a pretty hefty 5.8% ABV from the palate and body since it seems so light on its toes. Sessionable to be sure, and an ideal beer with finger foods - but not the kind of thing Id seek out for the taste alone.

12 oz. bottle from Woodmans Madison

Ar: Bit of honey.  Mild.  Light grassy hops.
Ap: Pours clear gold, white head, little lace.
T: Mild malt sweetness up front, nice hop profile comes through on the finish, a bit grassy.
P: Medium body, medium-high carbonation.

O: Quite good.
Transparent golden color in the glass. Grainy malt aroma and flavor, hint of noble hops. Sessionable, easy drinking.
Theres a surprising amount of sweet and floral flavor in Dortmunder Gold, despite its light color and body.  Its up there as one of my favorite light beers.
Nose is bready, malty, and bit of yeast. Flavor is the same as the nose with some citrus flavors. Light and easy drinking.
Bottle. Pours a clear gold with a thin white head. Aroma is grass and straw. Flavor is more of the same. Smooth and delicious. Would be a great everyday go-to beer.
bottle from craft beer outlet.  pours golden, with aroma of citrus/grass.  Also tastes citrusy/lemony.  pretty good

I think it is a little bitter on the back of my throat... not hoppy but hops are still present... the smell reminds me of a spring morning  after a good rain... a nice balance of malt. over all a good beer for grilling some brats or a good sirloin :)

Bottle via my buddy Art in trade.  A solid lager with a crisp lovely gold in the glass.  Gentle malts yield a nice cereal tone mixed with a light tingle of grassiness.  Subdued hop presence as needed.  Weaker nose.  A well prepared and unpretentious true to style beer.

This is probably the most popular craft beer int he Cleveland area.  I would be hard pressed to find a bar that didnt carry this.  Slightly sweet aroma, with a hint of biscuity malts.  Pours a clear gold, with a thin white head.  Not much going on in the flavor side, theres a bit of sweetness, and a kiss of hops.  Slightly floral, light and drinkable.  Ive never been a big fan of this one, it is quite popular in the area, and brings a lot of people over to the craft beer world.

A quality Dortmund style lager, the way the exported stuff tastes like in Germany (which always taste old by the time it reaches American store shelves). Bearing in mind its a lager (not an ale) Im not looking for the ale-like complexities that too many so-called beer connoisseurs seem to be looking for. This one is nice and clean, with cereal and yeast and that classic noble-hop nose. Perfect for a Sunday (or Saturday) afternoon of football and some grilled brats and kraut.

Pours gold in color, very clear, light carbonation. Small head, which dispersed quickly.  Pleasant, slightly hoppy, aroma.  Very smooth palate, balanced.  Lightly sweet, light bitterness.  Really liked this beer.  Light and easy drinker, but a lot of flavor.  A good "session" beer.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Pilsner glass.

Appearance: Clear, burnt gold with bubbly stark white head and nice lacing rings.

Aroma: Very fruity (apple, pear, lemon, citrus), with hay, fresh cut grass and peppery hops.

Taste: Great balance of malt and hops. Lots of fruit, particularly apple and lemon, which are augmented by high levels of hay, straw, and grass (almost too much for my liking). A decent level of noble hops provide a spicy, peppery and bitter counterbalance, but are kept in check until the aftertaste.

Palate: Moderately high carbonation, relatively full body for a pale lager. Fairly smooth, with a mostly dry finish.

Overall: Well balanced lager that truly shows what Dortmunders are all about. Smooth, crisp body is the highlight, as is the complexity, although there is just a little too much straw and grass flavors for my liking, but that is a minor gripe when the beer is so good.
Appearance medium amber head and foggy amber. Aroma is a plain corn malt. Taste is grain malt. Overall drinkable, but not great.
Aroma of bread, passionfruit, and malts.  Pours golden with a halfpint of foamy head.  Tastes delicious.  Malts, light fruits, floral.  Goes down easy but is full of flavor.  Like it.
Pours a bright, transparent copper. Extremely balanced and delicious with citrus hops and grainy malts.

The product meets the promise here, about halfway between pilsner and Marzen.  Bread and toast aromas are spiced with herbal hops.  The hops appear in the pour, leaving a light hop lace, with a typical light amber color.   Medium body, medium bitterness, soft carbonation, and lingering hops.   The final balance tilts toward pilsner but without the astringency.

Bottle in a weizen glass. There is no power due to a thunderstorm and all I have is cancel light. Based on that color is light amber and there is little head. Aroma is hoppy and that is it. Taste is bitter. This another beer I will not drink ever again.
Pours a clear copper body with a very thin but persistent white head. Earthy malts. Some caramel but quite crisp. Very easy to drink.

Poured a darker golden, clear.  Med head. Lite bitter, lite sweetness.  Aroma was little but consisted of fresh malts and grains with some stray floral hops. Lite bodied, slick, ave carbonation.  A nice smooth drinking lager.  Would get again.  It held a nice head.

Date: July 29, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Apple Valley Liquor, Apple Valley, MN Appearance: Translucent golden with slight amount of head and a little lacing.  Aroma: Good malt and hop balance.  Flavor: Consistent with aroma with a little spice, light to medium bodied, slight carbonation and a slight bitter finish Other: Really good for its style, but not sure I would buy it again.

I had this in a bottle at a friends BBQ.  Really traditional beer smell when you crack one open.  Slight burn in carbonation in the mouth.  Grain and wheat flavor.  This is one traditional German brew, but nothing special.

Tasted on 7/22/11 on draft at Inovasi.  Pours bright orange-amber with a thick off-white head that slowly recedes to an even layer of lace, leaving lacy residue along the inside of the glass.  The nose is malty with cereal, bread, and hay along with some grassy and spicy noble-style hops and just a hint of dusty yeast.  The flavor is a tad sweeter than the nose with the bread and cereal malts up front, moving to the grassy and spicy hops and the same dusty yeast character from the nose.  The body is medium with average carbonation and a long grassy, spicy, and lightly bitter hops finish.
This beer has a beautiful golden pour and has a delicious, complex  taste.  It is wonderful out of the bottle and exquisite on draft.

Bottle. Amber beer with a cream colored head. Malt and light mineral aroma. Malt and light hay flavor with light caramel and light mineral notes. Medium bodied. Malt and light caramel linger with light mineral and light grass.
Pours golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet malt with a good bit of floral hops. Flavor is some sweet caramel, lightly bready, lightly bitter earthy hops.
Nice blend of malt, hops and grain.  Very balanced and clean drinking, without being boring.  Nice.

Aroma is bread, vegetables.  The appearance is a nice red/gold, clear, white head.  The flavor is bready, grassy, vegetable. Medium in body.  The finish is noble hop bittering.  Nicely done  This beer made mee appreciate a style I dont normally like.

Aroma: very light, smell of wheat, not over powering and enjoyable.  Appearance:  Very beautiful deep gold, head is white but is small and seems short lived but may be due to glass.  Taste:  heavy wheat, bitter and dry at the end.  Palate:  goes down fairly easily, medium bodied.  Overall:  very enjoyable, not sure I could drink more than one or two at a time but is worth drinking if you are looking for an above average lager.
Bright gold color with a medium head. Crisp, clean, and refreshing. Biscuity flavor with mild spice notes. Medium bitterness. Nice if you want something with a light (but still flavorful) taste.

Had to catch myself and rate the last one of the six-pack before it ran out. This is a nice, well, gold color with minimal but pleasant head and lacing. Aroma is light dough, laced with caramel and some vegetal hoppiness. Flavor is nicely balanced and complex grain, clean and woodsy hoppiness. Really a perfect balance between residual sweetness and hoppiness here. Really good stuff.
Damn this beer rules. I am hard pressed to find any other good Dortmunder lagers with such frequency.
Bready and nutty aromas.  Medium bodied with good carbonation.  Nutty flavors with a little sweetness on the finish.  Overall a decent lager.
Apr 25, tap @ The Grest Lakes, Cleveland. Golden amber with nice lace. Refreshing, fruity, bitter hoppy, slightly sweet. Very pleasant fruity and bitter finish.

Has a bit of a soapy yeasty aroma. Pours dark golden with a big white head. Taste is clean and smooth with hints of caramel sweetness. Hard to believe this one is 30 IBUs since it doesnt seem bitter at all. If it werent 5.8% it might considered a good session beer. It will have to settle for lawnmower beer.

Bottle. Clear light marigold orange yellow; pure white head. Mineral and earthy hops in the aroma, dusty, and a bit doughy.  Very light hoppiness, but they are there...bready, some cereal, and a hint of earth.  Thinner, but substantial body.  I could drink this all-day long.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2016 Nice golden copper color with a frothy white head. Aroma of bread, yeast, grains, and noble hops. Nice mild, malty flavor with toasted grains and a balanced finish. Light body with soft carbonation. Pretty tasty.
12oz bottle shared by SoLan. Pours golden color. Nose is bready, malty, and bit of yeast. Flavor is the same as the nose with some citrus flavors. Light and easy drinking.
Draft. Poured a golden lager color, medium sized white head. Aroma was yeasty, bready, sweet malts. Flavor was a grainy, notes of yeast. Meh, it was good, but something lacking overall.

12 oz Bottle.  Appearance is deep golden yellow with medium head.  Aroma is bready and yeasty with a slight earthy note.  Taste is mostly sweet malts with accents of bread, cereals, and bit of grassy hop flavor.  Bitterness is almost non-existent.  Great example of the style.

(bottle) clear deep golden colour with small white head; aroma of noble hops, balanced flavour with long medium bitter finish; I am not a big fan of the style but it is the best dortmunder I have had so far
Pretty basic taste, nothing too out of the ordinary. Goes down pretty smooth, little bit yeasty, overall not bad, would drink again
Same bottle as pictured. Poured darker than the average helles which is clear golden brown. Very easy to drink with light malt with barely any hop bitterness at all. Very good.

Bottle from jlanning215.  Sweet grain and caramel aroma with corn and grassy notes joining.  The color is gold; this pours with a nice thick off-white head that yields thick lacing after practically each sip.  This is crisp and refreshing.  Sweet malt; grass, corn, wheat, hay flavor, somewhat silky, before drying out in the finish with crisp hops.  Nicely balanced.  Good stuff.

Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold is a clear, solid, sparkling golden lager with a big, frothy, bubbly white head that has outstanding retention and lacing.  It has a bready, yeasty aroma.  It smells a little grainy a little fruity.  It has a lively medium body with a metallic feel and a slightly gritty finish.  It tastes malty, but not sweet.  It has a twangy, slightly funky flavor.  Theres a slight juniper bitterness and alcohol in the finish and the aftertaste is hoppy.  Is there fusel detected here?  This is not really my thing.  It seems kind of like a malt liquor.

What an awesome beer. Pours a clean straw yellow with two fingers of sticky white head. Nose is sweet and bready with notes of strawberries and spicy herbal hops. Spicy citrusy flavor with lots of sweet bready notes. Very nice lager. Dry spicy palate. Mucho gusto

This is a great brew for sure. Awesome! Im not running to find Lagers but Id drink this everyday for my sessions of extended overboozing. Not so impressed with the aroma but the pour is fantastic. Crystal clear gold with nice white head that fades. That taste is great. Tons of flavor. Bright and crisp with a malt sweetness and the finish is what I love. It finishes dry and leaves you wanting. Fantastic.
Pours clear light amber color with white head. Aroma of biscuit malts and some floral hops. Flavor is bread and caramel with mild hops. Light to medium body with mild carbonation. Very nice
Bottle. Gold/amber, clear, white head that fades. Malty aroma with caramel, bread, very little in the way of hops. Dry and malty, light bodied. Pretty solid for the style but Im not a huge fan.

Pours clear orange-yellow, with white head.  Lively carbonation.  Aroma has notes of nice bread, touch of grass and pine.  Taste is a nice body, with a slightly creamy texture, with notes of sweet biscuit, grass, touch of nuts and sweet fruit, finishing slightly tart and bitter from the carbonation.  Nice brew.

12 oz bottle...poured golden yellow  / clear / off-white head...good lacing. Malt, caramel, bread, biscuity sweet on the nose...flavor was similarly sweet, but well balanced...average carbonation, medium bodied, clean finish...very tasty beer!
Bottle from Cavie.  Medium yellow pour with a white head.  Aroma is very bread, some grass, cardboard, and vegetation.  Taste is old carrots, lots of grain, and kinda butter.

Bottle courtesy weihenweizen. Pours a clear orange color with a white head. Foamy. Aroma is buttery and sharp metallic grains. Some moldy notes on the nose. Flavor is sharp malts with some tart notes. Small fruit in this but otherwise not great. If this is the best beer of this style then I just really do not care for this style. Sorry guys.

355ml bottle from jsprime. pours golden with a white head that lingers and laces. aroma of fresh barley malt and nobel hops. super clean balanced lager flavour. tight balanced bitter finish. hella drinkable. awesome stuff, thx jeff!
light texture, dry but not unpleasantly so. Very good aftertaste, flavor is excellent. Flavors complement each other wonderfully. For $8.99/6, this is a great value.
Very average, a little too roasted for my tastes and for this style. Little depth of flavor, which is typical of Lagered beers but considering this beers rating, I was expecting much more.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2011 I rated this 2.8 in February 2011, mostly because I believe I had an old bottle.  Trying it again now, its a revelation.  Good wheat and malt with a subtle spice and hoppy overtone.  Very drinkable, one of Great Lakes best.
Fairly crisp but a bit watery. Too close in relation to the shitty lagers of old.  Probably a decent summer beer but not something I could drink regularly.

Pours a clear amber with thick frothy, white head. Aroma is a mix of a lot of barnyard notes-mainly hay with almond notes. Flavor is a mix of hay a very light bubblegum flavor with nuts, grass. Body is light and carbonated. Refreshing.
This beer was hard to get down. It may have one awards, but isnt for everybody.

An orangish/amber color.  Clear.  Off white colored head that was small and didnt have much retention.  Did have some nice lacing and several bubbles rising form the bottom.  Nice bit of malt in the aroma.  Caramel, bread and a toasty biscuit.  It smells clean and well balanced.  The taste matched the aroma perfectly.  Caramel, bread and biscuit.  It did add an additional flavor of a light grain.  Only a minor touch of bitterness.  Medium mouthfeel.  Dry and crisp.  Left plenty on the palate.  This is really a pretty nice little beer.  Solid all around.  Easy drinking and balanced well.  Worth a try.  Could be enjoyed year round.  I dont think I would turn this down.

Bottle.  Pours golden with an orange-ish tint.  The head is thin and doesnt retain too well.  The aroma is fresh apples, maybe a little pear, some orange, and a dash of caramel.  It all blends together so well, its intoxicating.  The flavor hits well in all areas.  The citrus notes hit your senses first, then the caramel, then finally, a nice clean hop finish that makes its presence known, but isnt overwhelming.  The mouthfeel is light, bordering on medium.  This brew is substantial in flavor, but light enough to not leave you bloated after 1 or 2.  The ABV is near 6%, which surprises me given the relative lightness in mouthfeel.

This brew is very much on point, and easily my favorite to date.  My only complaint is that its just a tad bit heavy on the carbonation side, and theres not much head to speak of.  Other than that, its just about perfect.
Nice color, redish-blond. Sweet malty aroma. Nice balance, not dry but slightly hoppy.  Very sessionable beer.
Nice malt/hop balance and very easy to drink.  A little dry but at the same time not too much.

Bottle, as pictured.  Ive had this many times before but apparently never rated it.  Pours a crystal clear golden brown.  Lots of little islands in the white head.  Tastes of a lot of malt, some subtle sweetness.  Caramel and such.  Really smooth flavor.

12 oz bottle  - Pours a golden color with a nice thick, white head and plenty of carbonation bubbles. Has a nice crisp malty aroma along with lots of citrus - mostly lemon. Plenty of malt based flavor with some very nice notes of fruit (again - lots of lemon) and honey with a light hop bitterness that balances out this solid brew. Enjoyed this much more than I was expecting to.
Bottle at Chappys. A solid golden ale that contains moderate sweetness and well balanced hops. Nothing extraordinary but light, drinkable, and refreshing. A great craft intro beer.

Poured into a flute.

3.5 A: Clear golden yellow color. Two inches of frothy head with less than average retention and minimal lacing.

4.0 S: Sweet neutral maltiness, not really bready. Faint herbal hop aroma. Not strong, but really elegant aroma.

4.5 T: This is one tasty brew. It has more taste than would be expected in a light colored, low hopped brew. Grainy malts, and to a greater degree, bready malts. Low bitterness and hop flavor, but it works really well.

5.0 M: Medium body. Good carbonation. Really creamy that makes it seems like a heavier body than it is.

4.0 D: It tastes so damn good, but its a little on the sweet side so it reduces the drinkability.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-10-2009 05:18:30

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2011 Aroma: A nice malty nose, almost like bread and fresh grain, with just the slightest hint of hops underneath.
Appearance: Clear orange-gold color with a frothy white head.
Taste: Light bitterness, but still appetizing. 
Palate: Light-medium body, slick texture, average to soft carbonation, decent finish.
Overall: Living in Cleveland, this is the go to beer for everyone I know, so I think its become second nature for me to love and appreciate this. This is very solid, easily drinkable, good with anything beer.

On tap at Sheffields. Pours a lightly hazed golden colored body with a finger-width, frothy, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is some bready malts with a light sweetness, some grainy caramels, and a light floral fruit with just a touch of spice. Flavor is similar. A bit of a toasty, grainy caramel with some floral fruits and a touch of grass and hay before this finishes with a clean, light bitterness that dries and leaves a medium length aftertaste. Light-medium, smooth body with a moderate, soft carbonation. Very smooth drinking beer. Overall, a solid helles. Quaffable and easy drinking while being fairly flavorful. Nice malt backing with a clean, even hop balance.

Served as a bottle at Pizzazz in University Heights, OH. Pours a beautiful amber gold. The head fades quickly. Smells slightly hoppy, with malt notes and a nice overall spice. Tastes fantastic. Has a nice sharp, crisp, and clean yet slightly hoppy finish. Flat out one of the best Dortmunder beers I have ever had. Evident by its rankings and awards at competition.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2016 Sixer from Liquor Barn (Jefferson Commons); dated 10/10/16. Aroma: Semi-sweet bready malts that also have a sugar cookie-like quality; heavy herbal lemon lozenge besides. Appearance: Pleasant gold color with average carbonation holding up a foamy white head that settles into a patchy ring. Flavor: Lemon frosted sugar cookie up front; the heavy herbal lozenge presence returns towards the finish and comes off as astringent; you can feel every bit of the 5.8% here. Palate: Medium body, sticky texture, average carbonation, bitter finish. Overall: I remember liking this quite a bit more; personally, I think the hop treatment towards the finish is too heavy-handed. Not one I plan on buying again anytime soon.
12oz bottle.  Aroma of light roasted malts.  Flavor similar to that of a pale lager with a little more malts.  Not the best styles of beer.

Pours a deep gold color with a medium creamy white head. Wonderful aromas of biscuity malts and some hops peeking through. Sweet malts tickle your tongue at first, followed by some hop bitterness. Nice sweet/bitter finish.Nice solid body on this brew as well.Wonderful brew!
12 oz bottle, pours a pristine gold w/ foamy white head, aroma of light biscuit, flavor is dominated by biscuity/crackery flavors, smooth, great sessionable helles

Appearance:  slightly cloudy amber gold, quickly dissipating head but lots of residual lacing.  Aroma:  sweet grains and caramel; a light nose; slightly skunky.  Taste:  sharp, crisp, peppery; sweet toasty grains balanced with a slight bitterness.  Finish:  medium, tart, dry and slightly hoppy. Notes:  Not bad.  A little more bitter than the usual lager, but nicely balanced.  After reading all the reviews below, something tells me I may have gotten a bottle past its expiration date; my sampling would not seem to be in line with what the other reviewers have encountered.  Looks like Ill need to retry this one.
pours clear deep gold, with a moderate head. Aroma is honey and gingerbread.  Full body with balanced finish. Taste is rich, very slight hops to balance.

Poured from a bottle into lager glass.  Pours clear, golden with a medium, frothy head.  Nice balanced aroma with no real distinct notes.  Also, a very balanced taste with a little bit of everything.  Medium body with a thin texture, good carbonation and a smooth finish.  This is a great gold lager (especially for the price) and would go perfectly with almost any meal.

Nice dark gold look and puffy, rocky white cap. Crisp but lightly rich lagery aroma, taste is lightly fruity and has a crisp edge. At first it seems peanutty (oh no!) but this goes away and I get hints of lemon, apple and grape under a bold and toasty pale malt taste. I like this and think its good, probably amazing with some Schweinbraten mit Senf while relaxing under a beer tent. Yes this is food beer right here. Sausages hens and roasts.

Bottle via trade with jsquire, thanks Jeff! Pours a clear, dirty gold, with a 3 finger, fluffy, white that has great retention. Aroma is sweet and grainy malt, toast, light floral and spicy hops, toasted nuts and sweet hay, simple, but fantastic. Flavor is cereal, sweet grainy malt, sweet hay and raw nuts, finishes with sweet cereal and floral hops. Palate is lightish bodied, off dry and a touch slick throughout with a light, but sharp carbonation. Very tasty, well balanced helles.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 G: Pilsener glass emblazened with the Pilsner Urquell logo.

A: Poor a rich dark gold with a single-favor ivory head. A very good amount of carbonation coming up, although it does not appear to be overcarbonated a la many BMC lagers. Other than the colored hue, this is pretty much transparent. Head retention is quite good. 

S: Sweet grains, Batman! The grains come through with a mild sweetness. Slightly hoppy, but the hop aromas are only barely present. 

T: Very rich and slightly sweet, with a definite grain-malt backbone. Very fresh and clean--especially given that this babys best buy date is a mere two weeks away.

M: A good amount of carbonation, although the whole beverage is so smooth its almost as if its not ever there. Only the slightest hint of the 5.8 ABV. 

D: This one is hard to put down, and after taking the first few sips of my first, I already know that Id like another. Excellent drinkability. This is not to mention the fact that Im in Chicago, where its currently a blistery 29 degrees--I cant imagine how much more appropriate thisll be in the middle of the summer while grilling up a few items.

Aroma: faint grain/yeast, faint hops, smells like being on a brewery tour (saying this in a complimentary way); Appearance: beautiful gold, slightly lighter than honey, medium thick white head on pour, good stream of bubbles; Taste: wonderfully refreshing, like advertised, this really is a delicate balance between hops and malt, hops are floral or citrus, malt is grainy and light but not caramel, hops confronts taste buds initially, followed by the malt, a little more hoppy than malty; Palate: again, very refreshing, carbonation gives a very good nose-feel and blends the flavors in the taste; Overall: yet another great brew from Great Lakes Brewing, Im not familiar with if/how this style technically differs from a golden lager, but, Id say this is one of the best "golden lager looking" beers Ive ever tasted

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a nice clear darkish gold with an average white head.  Aroma of malt, caramel and grassy hops.  Tastes somewhat sweet with touches of malt, caramel, citrus and hops.  Nicely balanced.  Nice beer.
12oz pours a brilliant lively light copper.  Aroma is lightly flural with a little malt.  Taste is very dry with an awesome balance of malt and hopps  by far the best session lager ive had

Enjoyed on tap at the Bad Apple in Chicago, IL while signing the papers for my life insurance contract.  Fantastic brew, one that should be enjoyed after a long days work.  Aroma faint, light malt and hops.  Appearance is crystal clear amber with thin head.  Taste very crisp, slightly sweet for a lager but the malt/hop balance is fantastic.  The hops actually shine through in the mixture.  Great lager, Ive gotta get a six pack ASAP!

12 oz. bottle. Good, dry, noble, Continental European hops are noteworthy in the aroma. Biscuit, cookie, and saltine cracker scents. Light floral notes. Mouthwateringly appetizing aroma, though it is not particularly complex. Pours a deep, orangish gold to brass color. Clear. Moderate to large amount of slow-rising bubbles. Moderate amount of frothy, beige head. Pretty good lacing. Looks nice but not amazing. Salty, maybe even slightly briny flavor. Dry and hoppy. A hint of vegetation in the finish, especially zucchini. Less bready in flavor than the aroma implies. Dry, chalky, vegetal aftertaste. Medium body. Soft in the palate. Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold is not outstanding in any one category, but the whole exceeds the sum of its parts. This is a damn fine beer in a style in which it is difficult to produce a truly excellent brew in the grand scheme of things. It is a good beer to drink while watching football on a crisp October day, which is exactly what Im doing as I write this.

On tap at the quaker steak and lube in wheeling, wv. Aroma is malty and yeasty. Appearance is a hazy amber with a crisp white head. Taste is malty, yeasty, and hoppy with a satisfying bitter finish. Lacing is splotchy. I like this a lot. Very refreshing.
It is gold.  Beige foam.  Husky grain aroma.  Taste is some fruit, apple, caramel, toast and some grainy husks.
Bottle:  Poured a golden color with a white head.  The aroma was malty and hops.  The flavor was sweet malts and bitter hops.  Nicely balanced and easy to drink.

Bottle. pour is clear golden orange with a light head. Aroma is grain and grass with some sweet malt. Taste is crisp and citrus hay or grass and malt. Palate is creamy mild carbonation and finishes chaulky. Solid!

Would have thought this would have gone over better in a Blind tasting with The Beer Doctor DrBayern, Uncle Steve, Brian the beer Pimp, Uncle Tom and Barrister Bob.  Everyone liked it better than me.  Poured a copper color, with no head.  The malty taste was alright but no real aftertaste for me.  One of my lowest rated beers of the night.
Picked up a 6 pack at the local liquor store, Chicago, IL.  Pours a light amber with a medium frothy head that laces well.  Aroma is bread and caramel malt.  Finsish is a tad bitter.

Im going to have to dissent with Satan on this one.   I dont find this to be a good example of a Dortmunder (oh, and sorry, bjcp) and I dont find it particularly drinkable anyway. Dark gold to light amber in color, topped by a solid head.   Sweet malty aroma with some light, minty hops.  Sweet pale malt flavor, which borders on candied.   Alcohol is apparent as well.   Some spicy, minty hops give a valiant effort, but this is just too big, sweet, and alcoholic.

Not a style I usually prefer, but I will try to rate this to style, not personal preference. A finger-thick layer of foam slowly fades to a persistent off-white film. The lacing is such that I can see each sip Ive taken, like a chronology of the beers short life in the glass. The nose is of biscuit, caramel/toffee, cereal grain, walnut, leather, and worty sweetness. The flavour seems a bit maltier than other examples within the style, but Im not complaining! Its spiced by minty, almost herbal hops with accompanying sweet, nutty malts and a  fruityness resembling honey dew. The palate is sticky and mouth-coating, with sharp carbonation to cut through. I could drink a ton of these!

12 oz bottle from Princetons.  Very clear yellow pour with a couple fingers of fluffy head.  Aroma is a bit bready with some hops coming through as well.  Thin mouthfeel, clean crisp flavor with a nice hoppy bite coming through that lingers in the finish.

Bottle. Pours a very clean light reddish copper color with a 1 finger head of offwhite bubbles. Nice collar. The aroma that I get is a sweet malt and a touch of hops. Actually has an aroma like apples or pears. Interesting taste, sweet up front followed by a slight hop bite in the back but the sweetness really never goes away. Medium mouthfeel. 
Overall, not a bad smooth drinking beer.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a clear golden with a foamy white head.
S: Not much at all besides mild aromatic hops.
T: Smooth and malty, but a bit light on the flavor.
M: Light and very well carbonated. 
D: Very smooth and easy drinking. Highly recommended for sessioning.
Tap @ Great Lakes - orange, gold pour. Grassy, grainy. Nice caramel malt, hoppy balance. Nice warm finish.
Clear amber with a small white head.  Hay aroma.   Caramellish malts with piney hops.   Sticky palate.   Not a dortmunder.

12 oz. bottle. Appearance- Light amber color fair amount of head that doesnt last. Aroma- Malty with some toasty qualities and a noble hops. Flavor- Fair amount of sweetness in the front that balances out with dry bitterness that finishes clean. Palate- Lively carbonation. Medium body. Overall a well brewed lager that I could drink several of.
Dark golden color with a thick white head that left a lot of lacing on the glass. Spicy flavor with a hoppy finish. I really like all Great Lakes beers.

Poured from 12oz bottle, pours a nice golden color with white head that has lacing through out the entire glass, aroma has a wonderful balance of both malt and hops, a little on the sweet side, taste has a touch of hops and is sweet, delicious.

Bottle: Pours a Dark clear golden color, with modest white head and nice lacing during the drinking session. Smells slightly sweet, modest hops, flavors of the same, with a touch of malt. Lightly Carbonated, lightly bitter, Fantastic.
Excellent taste, nice hop and malt balance. Beautiful copper colour with just the right amount of carbonation. Clean finish.
Great summetime beer! A little bit sweet with caramel flavors and a slightly spicy finish.

Whole Foods, DC ($9.99): Pours a copper-gold color (definitely darker than I thought it would be) that leaves a good amount of lacing. Malty aroma, with hop notes on the side. Almost a creamy texture to it. Bitter hops (very much unlike German pilsener hops it seemed). Some grass and straw thrown in for good measure. Tiny bit of sugar. Quite well-balanced. More companies need to make more proper lagers and devote more time to their perfection.
Pours a yellow-orange color with no head.  Aroma of caramel and hops.  Crisp beer with a flavors of caramel, touch of hops, and bread.  Nice body for the style.  Very well done!
A good overall beer.  An old standby for drinking when the only alternatives are Budweiser or Coors.
Not typically a fan of golden lagers, but this one was pretty tasty.  Nice body and finish.  I plan to buy more of them.
This is very good. Seems like the Dortmunder that is almost a Vienna. Full bodied and maltier than expected. Serving: Bottle and tap

12 oz bottle from a sampler pack. bright golden color, solid white head. light aroma of hops and pine. nice taste of smooth caramel malt at first taste, just a bit of hop finish in the aftertaste. Nice summer beer.

I have been drinking this beer for years, but I guess I will finally rate it. Drinking from Bottle while night fishing for Catfish in Conneaut Ohio. Here comes a storm, lightning all around us. Better drink quickly. Starting off cold, Nice sweet malt, a touch of hops on the finish, a really nice smooth Lager. But as it warms, the flavors explode. Hard to pinpoint what the flavors are except it is a wonderful smooth Lager with exceptional balance that can be enjoyed all damn day....and night.

Finally got my hands on 12 of these puppies.  Thanks Pate.  I now understand why it is so highly rated for the style.  12 oz bottle to pilsner.  Pours deep golden with white head that laces nicely throughout the entire drink.  Floral hops with slight skunk and some bread.  Slightly sweet with a great lightly spicy finish.  Wonderful mouthfeel--full and creamy.  Glad I did not ask for just 6.  I am sold on this beer.

12oz pours copper/amber with nice frothy head. Aroma is sweet and slightly skunk, yeast, and grassy. Taste is very crisp of hops, honey, slight caramel. It tastes a little watered down but it adds to making this extremely drinkable. Very fine lager.
Nice flavor. A little bit watered down and a slightly bitter but decent for the summer time. Good not great.

Aroma is strong and crisp, malty and yeasty with a hint of honey sweetness. It pours a nice clear yellowish amber with a thick, if not persistent, white head. Flavor is richer than most golden lagers I have tried, malty and crisp with an interesting fruity undertone, the sort that I find mainly in ales. Texture is crisp and fizzy, leaving behind a nice tingle.

(Bottle) A replacement selection from Keg_Juggler for the week.  This is the first Ive tried the Dortmunder style. This is a nice alternative from an everyday pilsner with a bit more malt and sweetness. Poured a golden color with a lingering head & good lacing. Mild and easy to drink. Refreshing, very enjoyable.

Pours a copper-color, clear with a nice head that gathers around the edge of the glass and leaves some lacing. Bread and spicey hops in the nose. Very smooth, almost creamy with a long-lasting finish. The flavor is mildly sweet upfront with malty bread and balanced by a pleasing hops spiceyness. Really nice lager. Keeps me coming back for more and makes me want to drink more lagers.
Had on tap in Cleveland.  Great crisp flavor.  Had one before and after visiting the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.  Not a lot of head.  Good color.  Overall refreshing beer.
12oz bottle. Pours a golden color with bright white.  Lively carbonation. A little maltiness and nice noble hop aroma. Very good.

Bottle, via trade with miketd, light amber brown with white foam, bitter hoppy
aroma, flavors are nice minerally hops with soft caramel in the background,
Clean finish

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2012 Pours up a medium dark orange and it heads up.  I poured it to minimize head for some reason, and it still managed to foam up a bit.  It smells slightly of alcohol, but mostly of lager.  Its a good solid beer.  Its also my wifes favorite. Reviewed on 5/20/2012: I like it. One of the best lagers Ive had. This is a style I dont really like. Im an ale guy 100%. But I enjoy this beer.

Drank from a bottle at the Fox and Hound bar, just outside of Lake Norman, NY.  Aroma is very faint, little bit of maltiness.  Taste is clean with sweet malts and light hop flavors. Crisp clean finish.

Hints of caramel, honey, light graham cracker.  Hops are in the background on this one but that might be due to age.  Taste is sweet honey grain up front with a dry finish.  What a wonderful beer.  Nice balancing bitterness, and good carbonation.  Surprised that this one is 5.8%, I would have guessed lower at first sip.  Would recommend!

Orange-gold, frothy white head. Nose of milky grain, grass, honey, and a lightly refreshing berry. Flavor has more hop, some tea with a lingering grainy finish. Well balanced, particularly the flavor, and though the finish could use a bit more variety and length, the full body and lightly-fizzy carbonation go well with the soft profile..
Very nice indeed. Very nice aroma of malt and bred. Aroma of sweet malt and a bit of hops. Nice flavor that lingers into the night . Great while watching Roy Orbison, Bono, Springsteen, the Wilburys.

Another of ketchepillars Great Lakes offerings, thanks again Sam. Pours a golden color (of course) with  a nice enough looking head. The aroma has some spicy hops and some floral hoppy notes with a nice fruity and light bready character. We were talking as we drank this about how good German style lagers tended towards escaping words, in that it is very hard to describe them or compare the aromas or flavors to anything other than those associated directly to the style. My notes for this beer reflect this very well. There is some spicy noble hop presence in the flavor which provide a great bitterness. Not too much bitterness of course in the wonderfully clean lager featuring a light malt sweetness and some nice baguette notes. 

You cant find your waitress with a geiger counter.

A very nice example of the style. Malty, with slight biscuit. Woody, even. A little bit solventy, but not like the 2 women, or near as much. Tastes like this one cereal I used to eat, cant remember the name. Floral hops. I would like to try this super fresh, as i think this was bottled a couple months ago.

This has got to be my highest rated lager to date. This beer is absolutely perfect in terms of drinkability followed up with ample flavor and nuance. Pours out a honey colored yellow with a thick white head to start. Aromas of light caramel, nut, and toasted elements fill the air. Carbonation is light but steady and very balanced. Mouthfeel is quite impressive for a beer of this style and leaves more light roasty and doughy flavors on the tounge. A touch of grassy bitterness from the hops towards the end of the sip finishes the experience. Really good beer and would buy regularly if more available.

12oz bottle.   Pours a golden color with bright white head and lots of bubbling, lively carbonation.   A great lager aroma with a little maltiness and nice noble hop aroma.   A really nice malty taste which I feel most craft brew attempts at German lagers miss.  Finishes with a nice hop bitterness and dryness.  Real tasty.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2010 Body is golden.  No surprise here.  Sufficient white head.  Aromas of corn, slight diacytal, and hops.  Crisp lager.  Very good for the style.  Probably near the top.  A beer I would buy again.

Clear golden pour with a white head.  Aroma of crackers, fresh bread, and some leafy hops.  Flavor is mildly sweet with cracker and bready malts, light fruity sweetness. Very clean and nice.   Light to medium bodied, lots of nice carbonation.  Finishes malty with nice leafy hops.  Pretty nice beer.  One of the best from Great Lakes.
This is a great lager.  Copper color.  Very little hop presence.  Tons of dry malt.  There is a minor toasted character.  Very drinkable.

gold pour with a thin white head. 
aroma is biscuity malt and grassy hop. 
Flavour is more hoppy than I expected.
Grassy with bready malt and  light graininess.
Medium grassy bitter finish.

From 12oz bottle. Pours a golden hue with a small head and very little lacing.  Aroma has a nice malty bread like characteristic, with some hop presence. Taste sticks close to a traditional style Dortmunder. For an American representation of the style I think it hits the mark well. Very well balanced, I like the mouthfeel of this Lager alot.
user_location: Egg Harbor Township, New Jersey, USA

text: Bottle pours a golden yellow with a very thin white head that dissapates quickly.  Aroma is light on bread, caramel, malt, with a slight hoppiness.  Taste is carmel, bread, with a nice light residual bitterness.  No dms or diacytel present.  Light to medium body and carbonation.  Extremely well balanced beer.  As close to perfect representation of the style.

12 oz. bottle; thanks to alexsdad for the trade; clear dark gold with sporadic carbonation and white head to the edges; honey and grainy sweetness on the nose; light, syrupy texture with some bread and husky grains; pretty light and a little sticky; stale and pretty bland overall

12oz bottle. Pours copper with foamy white head, great lacing that lasts. Aroma is malty with bread and maybe a little grass. Flavor is a nice mix of malt and hops. A nice complexity on the dry finish, then a little bitterness. Carbonation is prevalent as well.This might be my new favorite from Great Lakes!

(bottle) Clear golden pour with a medium white head that holds well.  Aroma of honey butter spread on toast, honey-nut cheerios, musty lager yeast, caramel, and barley.  Taste begins sweet with plenty of honey poured over cereal, lightly grainy, barley, and caramel until finishing crisply with some dry mineral-like quality and hop bitterness that cuts right through the sweetness.  Nice dichotomy here between the sweet mid and dry finish.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is restrained.  This is just a great, well-balanced, infinitely sessionable beer that Im glad is now readily available here in the Twin Cities.  Would make for a great beer in the summer months.

Deep gold, medium head retention.  A good combination of sweet malt and dry hops; very american take on a Dortmunder style.  Aroma of pale malt and weedy hops; little complexity, but nice and clean.  Taste is fairly powerful sweetness and bitterness.  Medium body, crisp finish.  I prefer the original; this one is a bit to Americanized, a bit too pumped up.  But still a pretty good beer.
Tap. Clear amber pour with a nice retentive white head. Aroma is similar to a German Pils. Bready malty flavor with decent body.
A rich gold color with white head. Malt light aroma. Another good bottled lager. No defects and a solid body with mild hops.

Clear light golden with smallish, quickly dissipating white head.  Aroma is of lager yeast and faint floral hops.  Taste is mildly bitter though very well-balanced with light malt.  Medium-light mouthfeel and body.  Moderate carbonation and a very small sharp aftertaste make for a very good beer.  A great selection for noobs.

A- crystal clear pale amber body with bubbles floating to the top. A nice creamy color head remains at the top with great retention.

S- smell is of light hops and sweet malt.

T- a good light hop/malt mix. The initial taste is somewhat dull with a sweet caramel malt then the hops kick in. Its a refreshing kick in the mouth. The slightest bit of hop bitterness is at the finish. Sweet carmel remains beckoning you to take the next sip.

P- medium carbonation with a light body.

O- I will have this again. It was quite tasty and goes down easy. Its a great refreshing brew that goes with any meal and is great at any time of the year. especially summer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-02-2007 17:36:37
Poured to a golden color, clear, and a white short lived head. There is a sweet malt character on nose with a smooth malt taste and hop bitterness lurking in the finish.

12oz bottle. Poured a light amber/gold color with light white head. Aroma of hops and malts.  Taste is very smooth and has the hints of the American lager style beers.  This is a very smooth and balanced beer.  Easy to drink with just about any food selection.  Good quality Dortmunder.

Had this on draft and in bottles. Pours gold with a medium white head. Aroma is sweet with a hint of alcohol. Taste is the same. This is a very drinkable beer. Its hard to just have one. Overall, a very good session beer.

Had this from the tap.  Good Dortmunder style beer with American character.  Long lasting head around the glass well malted with a crisp hop profile similar to a Pils.  More on the pilsner side of the fence than a helles, but sweeter than a Pils (not as sweet as a helles).  Medium Carbonation.  Easy to drink.

3 bouteilles de 12 oz partagées lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal chez Fred82. Arôme: Légère odeur dagrumes et de céréales. Apparence: La couleur est dorée avec une très faible densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Léger goût dagrumes et de céréales. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de caramel légèrement fruité en arrière goût. (Rating #2987)

courtesy of tpd975.
pours amber-orange, white head.
Aroma is grainy, wheat, malty with a light roast and hops.
Flavors, similar to aroma, light fizzy/bittering palate, some pale malts and light roasted finish.
This bottle was beyond its bb date and the hops were more attenuated.

pours a deep golden orange-bronze with a light rose tint to it. head is thick and fluffy and off-white with tons of lacing. nose of citrus, bread dough, and a light funkiness. flavor is spicy, lots of citrus, nice bitter floral hop element, toast. slightly bubbly, but with a nice bite. dry, and even drier in the finish. pretty much the best helles Ive ever had. definitely in my top 10 session beer picks.

Draft at the Liberty on South Blvd, with Chris.  First Great Lakes brew.  Pretty good but didnt blow me away, to be honest.  Ill try it again, but I like this style a lot and I was expecting a lot from this brewery.
Pours a nice gold - exceedingly well balanced and very drinkable.  Nice malt level and hops levle- basically everything they said it was.

Pours a nice bronze gold color with white head.  Fair lacing.  Aroma is very mild with hints of bread and sweet flower.  Bitter on the front and back.  Some fresh citris and alcholol.  A great helles, but not my style.

Pours clear orange with a thing white head and some good lacing.  Aroma is round and soft with peach, warm spices and some subtle dampness.  Flavor is tangy fruit, some grapefruit peel and herbs.  finishes bitter but still fruity.  A very nice, refreshing beer that is simple enough not to think about but rewarding if you do.

A:  Pours golden hue with a small white head.  No retention or lace.

S:  Aromas of light bready malt.  Caramel, and ligh citrus.

T:  Simple sweet candy malts and a nice hop bite in the middle that carries through the finish.

M:  On the lighter side of medium, smooth.

12oz bottle thanks to bobsy.
Appearance : Clear yellow with medium creamy head. Nice lacing.

Aroma : Some alcohol, lots of malt. Some hops. Hints of caramel and grain.

Taste : Citrusy with lots of malt. Some hops but not that much. Hints of caramel. Finish is a bit warm and a tiny bit spicy maybe. Also citrusy and malty.

Overall : Highly drinkable beer. Tasty but the presence of alcohol seems inappropriate for this beer. Nice stuff but a bit boring.

Bottle.  Pours a coppery golden with a medium off-white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a lot of lacing.  Aroma is bready malt with a hint of citrus and floral hops.  Flavor is mildly sweet and very bready with some zesty hops.  Finishes dry and a bit bitter.  Creamy, medium weight mouthfeel.  Tasty, flavorful beer, particularly for a lager.  I wasnt expecting a whole lot and was pleasantly surprised.

Bottle from miketd, thanks Mike!  Poured a clear golden color with a half inch off-white head that faded to a layer.  Nose was a tad muted, but some light honey peaked through along with a moderate dose of grassy hops and a light fruitiness.  Smooth, moderately sweet entry with some light honey and fresh bread that leads into a lightly dry, soft grassy hoppiness that also seems to produce a lightly sour fruitiness that lingers into the finish.  I couldnt exactly tell whether this was intentional or not.  Low, tight carbonation created a vibrant mouth feel that balanced the sweet, heavy flavors with the lighter ones and kept the overall feel crisp.  Overall, I enjoyed this one, but it seemed slightly off.  I definitely need to revisit it when I have a chance.
had at st stevens after moving in. so sore. pour is clear orange gold. little head. aroma is weak. some hops and bread. flavor is smooth and mild. hints of alc. and hops.

Bottle.  Golden-orange pour with a bubbly, average white head.  Sweet grainy malt in the nose with light biscuit.  Flavor contains some bread dough and light crust with floral, earthy hops.  Very clean.  Medium body with lively carbonation and moderately bitter.  Super clean, tasty and well made.  Overall a very good beer.

Plusieurs bouteilles de 12oz et en fût. Arômes de houblon floral et de malt Munich. Robe dorée, légèrement cuivrée et translucide, légère mousse et effervescence moyenne. Très bien équilibrée, on retrouve des belles notes maltées légèrement caramélisées (malt Munich). Finale sucrée et légèrement amère de houblon floral. Très facile à boire et bien fait.

Bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Pours clear light amber color with white head. Aroma of biscuit malts and some floral hops. Flavor is bread and caramel with mild hops. Light to medium body with mild carbonation. Very nice. Thanks Peter.

As a native of Cleveland, Ill start off with the disclaimer that Im extremely partial to this brewery. That said, its merits easily transcend hometown pride, and the Dortmuder Gold is perhaps GLBCs best ambassador. Pity its not available out here.
12oz. Light aroma with a rather small head. Floral, mild pine. Where the beer comes alive is in the mouthfeel.  Its perhaps the ideal weight for a lager with enough heft to stand up to food and flexibility enough to be enjoyed in beyond responsible quantities. Slightly creamy as well, with a light hop finish.
What an American lager should be.
Great Lager, golden in color with offwhite head.  12ounce bottle from a multipack.  Wish my store sold it as a six pack.

Im really starting to like this brewer - have had 3 of their beers and they are all solid.  this one is surprisingly clear like their Pale Ale, but Im impressed with that given the solid aroma and taste.  This one is hoppy - almost like a cross between a lager and a pilsener.  Aroma has some bread and malt in addition to the hops.

12 oz bottle

I finally acquired and tried a bottle of this after hearing non-RB people have about it for years.  I dont know what they get out of it.  I think both this and the 20th are passable but hardly amazing beers.  On the other hand if this gives Great Lakes the funds to crank out Barrel Aged Blackout Stout and Lake Erie Monster more power to the people who keep them in business.

Aroma / Appearance - The yellowish body was more coppery than golden.  Transparent with a bubbly carbonation it looks like a safe alternative to the fizzy liquid that many people associate with the term "beer".  Fresh oak chips and a little bit of hops do not stir any sort of excitement.  A hint of citrus is about as complicated as this gets.

Flavor / Palate - The taste, from start to finish, is just like a teaspoon of honey spread over toasted wheat bread.  Pedestrian with a weak finish you could drink a sixer of these before you figured out what was actually going on.  Theres nothing particularly flawed about it; it just lacks anything special that would make me want to buy a bottle with my own money when so much more flavorful stuff is on the shelf at the same price point.
not bad, but not a whole lot too it...I like a good big nose in a beer, and there wasnt much of one...kind of bland but I think it was supposed to be...

Dark amber color with a medium white head that settles quickly and leaves moderate lacing.  Aroma of licorice and black pepper.  Flavor has licorice, lots of hops and lots of malts.  Could be better balanced.

Golden pour with a light offwhite head.  Aroma is light pils, some biscuity malt, and light floral notes. Body is medium light, with light carbonation.  Flavor is nicely floral, sweet toasted malt, with some biscuit, and a clean lagered finish.  Nicely done

Dammit, just missed getting rating 666 for this brew.  Bottle courtesy Googers and co.  Sweet malty nose, straw and Pils malt, light floral notes way in the back behind the faint citrus.  Clear golden pour with a sudsy white head.  Taste is clean, crisp, packed with flavor.  Floral notes are much farther to the front and mingle nicely with biscuit and bread crust.  Bright, meaty offering up front, darkens and dries into the long aftertaste (though it still cloys a bit with volume).  Silky, smooth medium-full body.  Easily among the best three or four Dortmunder made in America, and competes with the best that Germany has to offer.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2011 Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours a deep golden/light copper color with one and a half inch off-white head.  Taste is mostly bready malt with hops in the finish.  Best dortmunder I have had.

Are we sure this isnt an ale?  I usually wouldnt consider spending "good" money on a lager, but GL did a well...great job convincing me lagers can be full of taste.  Not the best aroma, but I really dont care...just hurts the overall a little.

Pours golden orange with a small white head. The aroma is bready malt with some hops and honey. The flavor is clean bready malt with some hops, honey, toffee and lemon. High carbonation and thin-medium mouthfeel.

Poured a clear amber, with a thin head that faded quickly.   Left no lacing.  The aroma is clean and citrusy, a light clear scent that reminds me of a small stream in the high Rockies that I drank from once when I was backpacking as a kid.

The flavor is strong  up front,  bitter with citrus and resinous tones,  settling nicely into a gentle toasty aftertaste that fades quickly.  A hint of spice appears as the beer warms.  The mouth feel hits as very rich, but by the end of the swallow its cleanly over.

Very drinkable beer -- every swallow invites you back for the next one, and wouldnt just a bit more be nice?   I could definitely session this.

Pours golden with a hint of amber.  Aroma is sweet malt with a hint of fruit.  Flavor is largely malt with a light hop finish.  Highly balanced with a subtle, yet comlpex malt profile thats hard to describe.  Good mouthfeel.
From an old rating note:  12oz bottle.  copper-gold pour with a thin white head.  Aroma is bread and wheat.  Caramel malt taste with light floral hops.  Crisp smooth finish.
Bottle, pours a nice clear amber with thick white head. Aroma, sour fruit, pear mostly, Taste, is thin bodied a little malty a little fruity but a lot not very big. very subtle.

12 oz bottle. Pours a  beautiful dark golden with some ruby glow and a thick frothy off white head.  Aroma is a nice blend of sweet bread and light fruits, both working in harmony. A little bit of cereal and just a hint of hay. Flavor starts with a sweet doughy character but picks up a light crisp bitterness fairly quick. Toffee and a toasted nut flavor becomes apparent before a crisp and slightly dry finish. Medium body and a soft carbonation. Really nice dortmunder, well balanced and very refreshing.

Light amber body with a decent, white head. Interesting lacing. The aroma is quite bready, yeasty even. Good carbonation, and the general mouth-feel is about medium in weight with the malt sweetness overpowering the hop finish. Overall, this is a very nice beer, and I have a feeling it would pair nicely with a number of different foods.

aroma is lightly floral hops and slightly unattractive grainy malt bill.  body is perfectly translucent bordering on orange.  flavor is nicely toasted malt that makes no reference to the aroma with a slightly bitter end that provides excellent balance.  palate is medium with a slight towards wet.

On draft in Cleveland, OH. Pours light amber with decent helping of head that quickly dissipates. First time trying this style. Flavor is sweet and floral with grass. Has a funny taste that Ive noticed with most Great Lakes beers, I think it is the water they use (the crystal clear water of Lake Erie?).

Bottle courtesy of markwise. Pours a clear amber to copper color with thin white head. Aroma is sweet and floral with notes of hay, grass, honey, light floral esters. Flavor is about the same. Light body with a light floral hop finish.

Amber pour from a 12 oz bottle. One fat finger of head that soon dissapates. Not much to the aroma, though what is there is clean and fresh. Very tasty - flavor dominated by malt but punctuated with decent hoppiness that smacks the back of the tongue. Satisfying mouthfeel with active carbonation. Good stuff!

Pours copper to amber color... Aroma is sweet and malty, nothing hoppy here. Flavor is carmelly with some biscuit and sweet malt. Nice medium light mouthfeel. Just enough hopping to provide some balance.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2009 Bottle via trade.  This beer is great for the style, an amazing light-colored lager.  Pours a bright clear golden color with a small white head that leaves a foamy ring around the glass.  Aroma is grassy and floral hops, pale malt, and grain.  Flavor is grainy yet very pleasant with pale bready malt, great grassy and fruity hops, and a little butter.  Flavor really jumps out.  Excellent palate, medium-light in body with a hoppy kick lasting on the palate.  Crisp and dry.  Great Dortmunder lager overall.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2010 Beer from trip to Westlake in September.

Aroma is slightly sweet - rather pleasant actually.  

Appearance is a decent brown.  Lightly sweet, lightly bitter flavor. Average carbonation.

A good lager beer.

Location: 12 oz bottle from jcos, 11/9/09


Aroma: It has lots of grains, biscuits, lemon, with some floral and earth

Appearance: Pours a clear golden-orange with a thin white head

Flavor: The taste is malty nd sweet (honey) with some nice hops for balance

Palate: This beer is very crisp, refreshing, smooth, and highly drinkable

Overall Impression: 
I have to say this beer really hits on the idea of being crisp and refreshing.  I love the way this one drinks, its got the typical flavors of the style, only stronger then your avvvvvvveraagge beer (I know, I know - bad Yogi Bear joke).  It really is quite a wonderfully made example of a Dortmunder.  Im not even a huge fan of this style, but this one really shows how good a well-made lager can be.  Now lets just hope Hanna-Barbera doesnt sue me...

Lots of carbonation bubbles rushing their way to the top of the glass. The aroma shows some honey, toasted grains, biscuit malts, and some floral hops. The flavor follows with the toasted, honey grains, biscuit malts, and some light bitterness from the floral hops. Medium bodied, smooth and easy to drink. Nice take on the style and a good tasting lager.

There is a nice biscuit graham cracker presence in the malt profile and Im also picking up some subtle faint light crisp fruit, mostly apple and pear. The hops provide a nice bitterness that is prominent up front and lingers above the complex maltiness into a nice dry finish. Very well balanced and very drinkable.

Like the medal which adorns her label, she pours liquid gold into my awaiting lager glass which practically glows from her golden straw brilliance. Make no doubt of it though, there is nothing unnatural or unearthly about this glow unlike some corn-crazy lagers I have come across over the years. A soft cloud of white settles lazily atop fields of golden hay which softly sway in the breeze, carrying a gentle and sweet aroma of ripe grains and Mother Nature. I havent stood in a field of harvesting grains in quite a few years, but I am sure this was what it smelled like in my younger years. Just down the street is a local bakers shop cooking warm fresh loaves of bread from those very same fields of grain while sweet rolls with a warm honey glaze sit already on the shelves for my senses to peruse. Is that lemon tree blossoms I smell in the background? If all my mornings smelled like this getting up would surely not be the chore that it is now. Wasting no time, I dive deep into her golden depths where I am embraced in mouth-coating soft sweet breads dipped in honey fresh from the beekeepers out back. Sweet rolls, butter rolls, white bread, fluffy and still slightly warm from the oven as lemon cream sneaks in for a peppy finish. Her mouthfeel is soft and lightly effervescent, practically floating across my tastebuds just as her cloud of white clings stubbornly to her surface. Only near the last quaff does a more forward bitterness make her presence known, offering a final flourish of perfection.


I now know why the Dortmunder Gold from Great Lakes has won multiple awards over the years with more to come, I am sure. Who needs lagers and pilsners when there is some Dortmunder Gold to be taken home, cradled, loved, and supped. Until Great Lakes makes it to Florida, I shall hopefully continue to savor her multitude of lip-smacking options with continual thanks to my friendly beer-gifters.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2013 Poured from bottle (8/2008).  Yeast/malt aroma.  Pretty amber with very thick white persistent head.  This is a lager loaded with malt and hop flavor.  Lacing.  Has a great old time lager feel to it.  Finished just fine.  A great lager.
